At its first official function of the
current year the Student Council
yesterday undertook to acquaint the
entering students with the Hopkins
honor system. Instead of employing
the usual method of arranging an
address to the group as a whole by
the Council president it was decided
to divide the new men into ten
groups to facilitate discussion.
According to Edward H. Sadtler,
president of the Council, this plan
was adopted to insure the completeunderstanding by every freshman of
the workings of the code and to
clearly explain every complication.
It was thought that this could be
done more adequately in a number
of small groups, he said.
In order to supply enough leaders
for the respective groups it was necessary to draw upon the activities

Pretty Good So Far
Sadtler's prompt attack upon the problems of
his new office as enforcer of the honor system has been
rather heartening to those of us who have looked forward to the firmer establishment of the code. The
idea of dividing the freshmen into groups to be acquainted with the system is not particularly novel,
but it has escaped all his predecessors in the office.
It was calculated to add weight to the impression
which must so necessarily be made upon entering
students.
The task of keeping the system upon a high level
of operation is no easy one. Constant effort and originality, together with a ready adaptability to new and
difficult situations must characterize the Council president. Sadtler's energy displayed so far promises well
for his success.
We await with no little anticipation the action
he will take in enforcing the code in the Engineering
School, which, although it has over half the undergraduate enrollment, has no representative on the
Council. His attention must also be directed to the
somewhat ludicrous provision of the code that even
though the student is "on his honor" he must not,
under any circumstances, leave the room during an
.examination. This regulation arose from what we believe to have been the inability of last year's Council
to cope with its problem and will challenge all the intelligent attention of the new membership.

Well, the paper is back in circulation after four
months of complete inactivity. It's going to be better
than ever; it's still going to be the only reliable means
of keeping closely in touch with all the important news
of your university; and it's still going to be the source
of comfort it has always been to those who, if their
NEWS-LETTER did not appear twice a week, would
would never have anything in their P. 0. boxes.
Of course, we didn't need to tell you all that.

Fellowships
Five new state fellowships in
chemistry were awarded to graduate chemical students from various
parts of the country, it was announced today by Professor J. C.
W. Frazer.
The new fellows are: William
W. Davis, Indiana, donated by the
Eli Lilly Company; Philip B. Onderdonk, Maryland, donated by Dr.
H. A. B. Dunning; Sutton Redfern, Washington, donated by The
Fleischmann Company; Charles F.
Squire, given at large, donated by
Patrick Garvan; John F. Taylor,
New York, donated by Francis P.
Garvan.
The chemistry department has
projected these fellowships to provide the means of a chemical education for prospective leaders in this
field. Each fellowship is $1,000 a
year and is available for four years.

Requests for graduates of the
Johns Hopkins School of Business
Economics have been far greater
than the number of unemployed
alumni it was revealed today by
Miss Judge, secretary of the Bureau of Appointments.
The number of part-time university jobs is unusually large, numerous students having been able to
secure jobs this summer. Students
who desire to receive part-time employment are requested to file an
application in the Bureau of Appointments, Remsen Hall, Room 17.

From one line to another, registration is one round of
signing cards and filling out blanks—and of course
meeting new and old friends. Here we have registration scenes as students returned to the campuses of
the University of Minnesota and Purdue University.
These familiar scenes were duplicated on every campus in the United States this month when many thousands of students returned to colleges and universities
to continue their higher education. Many aids were
given students by the institutions so that many were
enabled to return who would have been forced to stay
at home this year.

STADIUM NOW A DORMITORY
Ohio State University this fall has its first men's dormitory in 30 years,
and for the first time in history a stadium is being used as a rooming
house, for 75 freshmen and upperclassmen have just moved into this tower
in the Ohio State stadium. The dormitory is a cooperative venture for
the students, with room rates one dollar for 12 weeks, and board $2.50
a week.

One of the oldest college alumni in the United States, Dr.
James S. Barr attended his seventy-fifth class reunion at
Washington and Jefferson college this year. Dr. Barr is
100 years old, and was reported to be in failing health
when his class reuned in 1883. He was graduated in 1858.

Miss Jean Frazer, a junior at the University of Oregon, ruled this month as queen
of the historic Pendleton, Ore., roundup. Miss Frazer is a daughter of one of the
founders of the roundup, which was held for the first time 23 years ago.

THE JUDGES AND THE WINNERS IN FISHER CONTEST
These four American youths are the winners of the Fisher Body Craftsman's Guild model
coach competition, and the coaches that they constructed were adjudged the best in the country
by the group of outstanding judges shown in toe picture below. The winners, shown at the
left with Mr. W. A. Fisher, president of the Fisher Body Corporation, are Myron Webb, 15, of
Arkansas City, Kan., E. Stanley Webb, 15, of Baltimore, Md., Jack Wicks, 18, of St. Paul, Minn.,
and Charles Gadd, 18, of Spokane, Wash.
Grouped around the judges' table are: John Stiles, head of the Canadian Scouts and honorary
president of the Guild in Canada; H. J. C. Henderson (standing) secretary of the U. S. Guild;
C. H. Mitchell, dean of the faculty of applied science and engineering, University of Toronto;
the Rev. T. A. Steiner, C. S. C., dean college of engineering. University of Notre Dame; E. A.
Hitchcock. dean of engineering, Ohio State University; M. L. Brittain, president Georgia Institute of Technology; F. C. Riess, technical consultant of the Guild; D S. Kimball, dean of engineering, Cornell University; R. L. Sackett, dean of engineering, Pennsylvania State College;
H. V. Carpenter, dean of engineering, Washington State College; Walther Louschner, technical
consultant of the Guild; George J. Davis, Jr., dean of engineering, University of Alabama;
Thomas S. Baker, president Carnegie Institute of Technology; P. R. Kolbe, president Drexel
Institute, and Augustin Frigon, of the University of Montreal.

At its first official function of the
current year the Student Council
yesterday undertook to acquaint the
entering students with the Hopkins
honor system. Instead of employing
the usual method of arranging an
address to the group as a whole by
the Council president it was decided
to divide the new men into ten
groups to facilitate discussion.
According to Edward H. Sadtler,
president of the Council, this plan
was adopted to insure the completeunderstanding by every freshman of
the workings of the code and to
clearly explain every complication.
It was thought that this could be
done more adequately in a number
of small groups, he said.
In order to supply enough leaders
for the respective groups it was necessary to draw upon the activities

Pretty Good So Far
Sadtler's prompt attack upon the problems of
his new office as enforcer of the honor system has been
rather heartening to those of us who have looked forward to the firmer establishment of the code. The
idea of dividing the freshmen into groups to be acquainted with the system is not particularly novel,
but it has escaped all his predecessors in the office.
It was calculated to add weight to the impression
which must so necessarily be made upon entering
students.
The task of keeping the system upon a high level
of operation is no easy one. Constant effort and originality, together with a ready adaptability to new and
difficult situations must characterize the Council president. Sadtler's energy displayed so far promises well
for his success.
We await with no little anticipation the action
he will take in enforcing the code in the Engineering
School, which, although it has over half the undergraduate enrollment, has no representative on the
Council. His attention must also be directed to the
somewhat ludicrous provision of the code that even
though the student is "on his honor" he must not,
under any circumstances, leave the room during an
.examination. This regulation arose from what we believe to have been the inability of last year's Council
to cope with its problem and will challenge all the intelligent attention of the new membership.

Well, the paper is back in circulation after four
months of complete inactivity. It's going to be better
than ever; it's still going to be the only reliable means
of keeping closely in touch with all the important news
of your university; and it's still going to be the source
of comfort it has always been to those who, if their
NEWS-LETTER did not appear twice a week, would
would never have anything in their P. 0. boxes.

Fellowships
Five new state fellowships in
chemistry were awarded to graduate chemical students from various
parts of the country, it was announced today by Professor J. C.
W. Frazer.
The new fellows are: William
W. Davis, Indiana, donated by the
Eli Lilly Company; Philip B. Onderdonk, Maryland, donated by Dr.
H. A. B. Dunning; Sutton Redfern, Washington, donated by The
Fleischmann Company; Charles F.
Squire, given at large, donated by
Patrick Garvan; John F. Taylor,
New York, donated by Francis P.
Garvan.
The chemistry department has
projected these fellowships to provide the means of a chemical education for prospective leaders in this
field. Each fellowship is $1,000 a
year and is available for four years.

Requests for graduates of the
Johns Hopkins School of Business
Economics have been far greater
than the number of unemployed
alumni it was revealed today by
Miss Judge, secretary of the Bureau of Appointments.
The number of part-time university jobs is unusually large, numerous students having been able to
secure jobs this summer. Students
who desire to receive part-time employment are requested to file an
application in the Bureau of Appointments, Remsen Hall, Room 17.

FROM ONE LINE TO ANOTHER
From one line to another, registration is one round of
signing cards and filling out blanks—and of course
meeting new and old friends. Here we have registration scenes as students returned to the campuses of
the University of Minnesota and Purdue University.
These familiar scenes were duplicated on every campus in the United States this month when many thousands of students returned to colleges and universities
to continue their higher education. Many aids were
given students by the institutions so that many were
enabled to return who would have been forced to stay
at home this year.

STADIUM NOW A DORMITORY
Ohio State University this fall has its first men's dormitory in 30 years,
and for the first time in history a stadium is being used as a rooming
house, for 75 freshmen and upperclassmen have just moved into this tower
in the Ohio State stadium. The dormitory is a cooperative venture for
the students, with room rates one dollar for 12 weeks, and board $2.50
a week.

Seven colleges and universities in the United States this fall welcomed to their cam'Puses new administrative heads of their institutions. Heading the list of scientists
and educators that have been advanced to high administrative posts are James Bryant
Conant, president of Harvard University, Harold Willis Dodds, 15th president of
Princeton University, and Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of the New York University. Others who have been raised to presidencies include Harry S. Rogers, Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, John M. Munson, Michigan Normal College, Clyde A. Lynch,
nimat Lebanon Valley College, and Willfred 0. Mauck, Hillsdale, Mich., College.

The tallest structure in South Dakota!
The Coughlin Campanile on the campus of
the South Dakota State College at Brookings houses chimes which strike the hour
and the quarter hours, call classes, and
play two concerts a day. In addition to
all this, the top of the tower serves as an
aerial beacon visible at a distance of 100
miles.

One of the oldest college alumni in the United States, Dr.
James S. Barr attended his seventy-fifth class reunion at
Washington and Jefferson college this year. Dr. Barr is
100 years old, and was reported to be in failing health
when his class reuned in 1883. He was graduated in 1858.

Miss Jean Frazer, a junior at the University of Oregon, ruled this month as queen
of the historic Pendleton, Ore., roundup. Miss Frazer is a daughter of one of the
founders of the roundup, which was held for the first time 23 years ago.

THE JUDGES AND THE WINNERS IN FISHER CONTEST
These four American youths are the winners of the Fisher Body Craftsman's Guild model
coach competition, and the coaches that they constructed were adjudged the best in the country
by the group of outstanding judges shown in toe picture below. The winners, shown at the
left with Mr. W. A. Fisher, president of the Fisher Body Corporation, are Myron Webb, 15, of
Arkansas City, Kan., E. Stanley Webb, 15, of Baltimore, Md., Jack Wicks, 18, of St. Paul, Minn.,
and Charles Gadd, 18, of Spokane, Wash.
Grouped around the judges' table are: John Stiles, head of the Canadian Scouts and honorary
president of the Guild in Canada; H. J. C. Henderson (standing) secretary of the U. S. Guild;
C. H. Mitchell, dean of the faculty of applied science and engineering, University of Toronto;
the Rev. T. A. Steiner, C. S. C., dean college of engineering. University of Notre Dame; E. A.
Hitchcock. dean of engineering, Ohio State University; M. L. Brittain, president Georgia Institute of Technology; F. C. Riess, technical consultant of the Guild; D S. Kimball, dean of engineering, Cornell University; R. L. Sackett, dean of engineering, Pennsylvania State College;
H. V. Carpenter, dean of engineering, Washington State College; Walther Louschner, technical
consultant of the Guild; George J. Davis, Jr., dean of engineering, University of Alabama;
Thomas S. Baker, president Carnegie Institute of Technology; P. R. Kolbe, president Drexel
Institute, and Augustin Frigon, of the University of Montreal.

Following the group meetings, at
which papers will also be read by
delegates, The Sun will present its
motion picture film "Making of a
Newspaper" in Latrobe Hall. The
public is invited to this showing.
Later, delegates will attend a party
at the Hi-Hat Supper Club, where
Lou Lynn's 12-piece orchestra is
now being featured, together with
a New York floor show starring
Jackie Beekman, former Warner
Bros. picture star.
The Cotillion Board has invited
convention delegates to the dance
to be held in Levering on Saturday
night of the two-day meeting, at
the close of the I. N. A. formal banquet.
